awd_titl_txt: Impact of sumoylation and Wnt/beta-catenin signaling on nuclear receptor-regulated tissue-specific transcription
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual merit:  From the explosion of sequencing data over the last decade it is apparent that we have a significant number of genes in common with animals as similar as apes and as strikingly different as worms and flies.  How these genes are regulated, and when and where they are turned off and on, play a critical role in proper animal development, response to environmental stress and fluctuation, and are part of what makes animals with such similar genes so mesmerizingly different.  Proteins called transcription factors regulate genes by helping turn them on or off.  Intriguingly, the same protein can turn a single gene on in one tissue and off in another.  Despite decades of research on gene regulation we still do not have a strong understanding of how these proteins can exhibit such diverse, tissue-specific activity.  This project will harness a simpler animal, the worm C. elegans, to explore this biology. The worm is only 1 mm long, consisting of 959 cells, and goes from egg to adult in three days, yet has a vast number of genes and transcription factors in common with humans.  By studying how a single transcription factor works in three different tissues, in particular studying the influence of two regulatory factors, insight will be gained into how tissue-specific gene regulation works.


Broader impacts:  This project will establish and sustain a collaboration with an outstanding woman scientist from eastern Europe, Dr. Masako Asahina, and to train students from underrepresented minorities who are part of a special undergraduate research program. Professor Yamamoto shall also use his findings from this proposed research to broaden and enrich his teaching in a UCSF graduate course on Biological Regulatory Mechanisms, and in turn, will use the scope of that course and input from its students to inform our research. Finally, Professor Yamamoto will use these research and educational opportunities and outcomes as specific examples to enliven and empower his science and public policy efforts, and public communication and outreach activities at the federal level.

Our DNA is each individual’s unique “safe deposit box” of genes that determines in large part who we are, what we look like, and how we differ from others. Interestingly, each individual’s DNA is identical in each cell within that individual, despite the fact that the cells—e.g., brain, muscle, blood—are very different from each other. This is because each type of cell turns on, or expresses, only a particular subset of the genes in our safe deposit box—the brain, muscle or blood genes—and leaves the others turned off. Not only that, but our cells, our bodies, have evolved to be on the lookout for signals both within our bodies and in the environments we live in, and to respond to those signals—stress, hunger, air pollution—by changing the collection of genes turned on or off.

The expression of genes is controlled by a set of cellular proteins called transcription factors (TFs), and TF activities are themselves controlled by signals. We sought in this NSF project to better understand the remarkable specificity of TFs and their sensing and responses to signals. To do so, we studied a single TF, called NHR-25, and a single signal, a molecule called SUMO, that binds to NHR-25 in a process called sumoylation. These factors, signals and processes have been conserved throughout the evolution of complex organisms like humans; this says that they are important. We chose to study them in a simple round worm, called C. elegans, because of numerous advantages of that system for designing and interpreting scientific experiments, knowing that what we learned in C. elegans would be relevant in humans.

NHR-25 is expressed throughout development in multiple cells and tissues, with a role in formation of certain organs during development. We studied formation of the C. elegans vulva, as we know when and where every single cell divides and how they fuse and migrate in order to make the organ. Six vulval precursor cells (VPCs) undergo an invariant process of cell division, cell-type decision, migration and fusion to ultimately form the 22-cell reproductive organ. Each of these six cells has the capacity to become three distinct cell types; a complex set of signals results in a specific cell type decision. These signals ultimately affect the sets of genes expressed in the VPCs, and those sets of genes are controlled in part by NHR-25. Through biochemical and genetic experiments, enabled in part by new methods that we developed and  refined, we discovered that NHR-25 can be sumoylated during development, and that this signal affects the way that NHR-25 regulates cell-type decisions during vulva formation. In fact, without sumoylation, NHR-25 promotes aberrant cell-type decisions, leading to gross developmental abnormalities.

Thus, we found that both the NHR-25 TF and the SUMO signal play essential and interactive roles in ensuring correct cell-type decisions during organ formation, and we began to identify the exact genes whose expression was controlled by NHR-25, and how that expression was modified by sumoylation. Understanding these mechanisms in this simple experimental system will help us to determine how gene regulation and signaling works with other factors, and in more complex systems. Moreover, the new methods we developed will help to advance other research programs in other labs, in other experimental systems, and in a range of fields, including but not limited to aging, neurobiology, cancer, cell death, and development.
